whatIsAI.title: What is Artificial Intelligence?
whatIsAI.description: Understanding AI, its types, and real-world applications
whatIsAI.overview: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the simulation of human intelligence in machines programmed to think and learn. It encompasses everything from simple automation to complex decision-making systems. AI has transformed industries from healthcare to entertainment, making it one of the most important technologies of our time.
keyPoints: AI mimics human cognitive functions like learning and problem-solving
Three types: Narrow AI (current), General AI (future), Super AI (theoretical)
Machine Learning is a subset of AI that learns from data
Deep Learning uses neural networks to process complex patterns
AI is used in smartphones, recommendations, autonomous vehicles, and more

virtualAssistants.title: Virtual Assistants
virtualAssistants.description: Siri, Alexa, Google Assistant use NLP to understand voice commands
virtualAssistants.example: Ask 'What's the weather?' and AI processes language, fetches data, and responds

recommendationSystems.title: Recommendation Systems
recommendationSystems.description: Netflix, YouTube, Amazon suggest content based on your preferences
recommendationSystems.example: Watch action movies → AI learns preference → Recommends similar content

medicalDiagnosis.title: Medical Diagnosis
medicalDiagnosis.description: AI analyzes medical images to detect diseases early
medicalDiagnosis.example: Scan X-rays for cancer with 95%+ accuracy, faster than humans

selfDrivingCars.title: Self-Driving Cars
selfDrivingCars.description: Tesla, Waymo use AI to navigate roads autonomously
selfDrivingCars.example: Computer vision + sensors detect pedestrians, traffic signs, obstacles

dos: Start with understanding basic concepts before diving into code
Explore different AI applications to see what interests you
Learn Python - it's the most popular AI programming language
Stay updated with latest AI developments
donts: Don't expect to build complex AI overnight - it takes time
Don't skip the math fundamentals (statistics, linear algebra)
Don't rely only on theory - practical implementation is crucial
Don't ignore ethical implications of AI systems
Don't get overwhelmed - take one concept at a time
bestPractices: Follow a structured learning path from basics to advanced
Build small projects to reinforce learning
Join AI communities and forums for support
Read research papers to understand cutting-edge work
Experiment with different AI tools and frameworks

aiMlDl.title: AI vs ML vs Deep Learning
aiMlDl.description: Understanding the relationship between AI, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning
aiMlDl.overview: AI, ML, and DL are related but distinct concepts. Think of them as nested dolls: AI is the outermost layer (broadest concept), Machine Learning sits inside AI, and Deep Learning is a specialized technique within ML. Understanding these distinctions is crucial for navigating the AI landscape.

diagram.title: The Relationship Between AI, ML, and Deep Learning
diagram.description: AI is the broadest field, ML is a subset of AI, and DL is a subset of ML

layers.ai: Artificial Intelligence - Machines that can perform intelligent tasks
layers.ml: Machine Learning - Systems that learn from data
layers.dl: Deep Learning - Neural networks with multiple layers

comparisonTable.title: AI vs Machine Learning vs Deep Learning
definition: Systems learning from data without explicit programming
Neural networks with multiple layers learning hierarchical features
scope: Subset of AI focused on learning
Subset of ML using neural networks
dataRequirements: Varies (can work with little or no data)
examples: Rule-based chatbots, game AI, expert systems
Spam filters, recommendation systems, linear regression
Image recognition, speech synthesis, language models

keyPoints: AI: Broad field of making machines intelligent
ML: Subset of AI that learns patterns from data without explicit programming
DL: Subset of ML using neural networks with multiple layers
AI can exist without ML (rule-based systems)
DL requires large amounts of data and computing power

ruleBasedAI.title: AI without ML: Rule-Based Chatbot
ruleBasedAI.example: If user says 'hello' → respond 'Hi there!'. No learning involved.

mlSpamFilter.title: Machine Learning: Spam Filter
mlSpamFilter.description: Learns to identify spam from labeled examples
mlSpamFilter.example: Train on 10,000 emails (spam/not spam) → Predicts new emails accurately

dlImageRecognition.title: Deep Learning: Image Recognition
dlImageRecognition.description: Neural networks identify objects in photos
dlImageRecognition.example: Show 1M cat pictures → Network learns features → Recognizes cats in new photos

typesOfAI.title: Types of AI: Narrow, General, and Super AI
typesOfAI.description: Categorizing AI based on capabilities and functionality
typesOfAI.overview: Artificial Intelligence can be categorized based on its capabilities and functionality. Understanding these types helps you recognize what's currently possible, what's being researched, and what remains science fiction.

narrowAI.title: Narrow AI (Weak AI)
narrowAI.description: AI designed to perform a specific task. All AI systems we use today fall into this category - from virtual assistants to recommendation engines to self-driving cars. Each excels at one task but cannot generalize to others.

generalAI.title: General AI (Strong AI)
generalAI.description: AI with human-level intelligence across all tasks. It can learn, understand, and apply intelligence to solve any problem that a human can. This doesn't exist yet and is the focus of ongoing research.

superAI.title: Super AI
superAI.description: AI that surpasses human intelligence in all aspects. It's purely theoretical and raises important ethical and existential questions about the future of AI.

keyPoints: Narrow AI: Specialized in one task (all current AI)
General AI: Human-level intelligence across all tasks (not yet achieved)
Super AI: Exceeds human intelligence (theoretical)
Current technology is exclusively Narrow AI
AGI (Artificial General Intelligence) is the goal of AI research

narrowExamples.title: Narrow AI Examples
narrowExamples.description: Siri (voice assistant), AlphaGo (game playing), Tesla Autopilot (driving), ChatGPT (language), DALL-E (image generation) - each excels at its specific task

whyGeneralAIHard.title: Why General AI is Hard
whyGeneralAIHard.description: A chess AI cannot drive a car. A language model cannot diagnose diseases without specific training. Current AI lacks transfer learning and common sense reasoning

agiChallenge.title: The AGI Challenge
agiChallenge.description: Creating AI that can learn new tasks like humans do, understand context, reason abstractly, and apply knowledge across domains remains unsolved

aiApplications.title: Real-World AI Applications Across Industries
aiApplications.description: How AI is transforming every industry
aiApplications.overview: AI is transforming every industry imaginable. Understanding where and how AI is applied helps you identify opportunities in your field and appreciate the breadth of AI's impact on modern life.

healthcare.title: Healthcare
healthcare.description: AI analyzes medical images, predicts diseases, discovers drugs, and personalizes treatment plans. Systems can detect cancer in X-rays with accuracy matching or exceeding human radiologists.

finance.title: Finance
finance.description: AI detects fraud in real-time, trades stocks, assesses credit risk, and provides personalized financial advice. Banks use AI to prevent billions in fraudulent transactions annually.

transportation.title: Transportation
transportation.description: Self-driving cars, traffic optimization, route planning, and predictive maintenance. AI processes sensor data to make split-second driving decisions.

retail.title: Retail
retail.description: Recommendation engines, inventory management, price optimization, and visual search. Amazon's recommendations drive 35% of their sales through AI.

manufacturing.title: Manufacturing
manufacturing.description: Quality control, predictive maintenance, supply chain optimization, and robot automation. AI reduces defects and downtime significantly.

keyPoints: Healthcare: Medical imaging, drug discovery, diagnosis
Finance: Fraud detection, trading, risk assessment
Transportation: Autonomous vehicles, route optimization
Retail: Recommendations, inventory, customer service
Manufacturing: Quality control, predictive maintenance

medicalDiagnosis.title: AI in Medical Diagnosis
medicalDiagnosis.description: Google's AI detects diabetic retinopathy from eye scans with 90%+ accuracy. IBM Watson helps oncologists identify cancer treatment options based on medical literature.

fraudDetection.title: AI in Financial Fraud Detection
fraudDetection.description: PayPal uses AI to analyze millions of transactions per second, identifying suspicious patterns and blocking fraud before it happens. Saved $2B+ annually.

contentRecommendation.title: AI in Content Recommendation
contentRecommendation.description: Netflix saves $1B yearly by using AI recommendations to reduce churn. 80% of watched content comes from recommendations, not search.

agriculture.title: AI in Agriculture
agriculture.description: John Deere uses computer vision to identify weeds and spray only where needed, reducing herbicide use by 90%. Drones monitor crop health using AI.

aiEthics.title: AI Ethics and Responsible AI Development
aiEthics.overview: As AI becomes more powerful and widespread, ethical considerations become critical. Responsible AI ensures systems are fair, transparent, accountable, and beneficial to society.

bias.title: Bias in AI
bias.description: AI systems can perpetuate or amplify human biases present in training data. A hiring AI trained on historical data might discriminate against women if past hiring was biased.

privacy.title: Privacy
privacy.description: AI systems often require vast amounts of personal data. Balancing AI capabilities with user privacy is a fundamental challenge.

transparency.title: Transparency
transparency.description: Many AI systems are 'black boxes' - we don't understand how they make decisions. This lack of explainability is problematic in high-stakes domains like healthcare and criminal justice.

accountability.title: Accountability
accountability.description: When AI makes mistakes, who is responsible? The developer? The company? The user? Clear accountability frameworks are needed.

jobDisplacement.title: Job Displacement
jobDisplacement.description: AI automation may eliminate certain jobs. Society must prepare for this transition through education and policy.

keyPoints: Bias: AI can inherit and amplify human biases from data
Privacy: AI systems need data, raising privacy concerns
Transparency: 'Black box' AI lacks explainability
Accountability: Unclear responsibility when AI fails
Fairness: AI should treat all groups equitably

facialRecognition.title: Facial Recognition Bias
facialRecognition.description: Studies show facial recognition is less accurate for people with darker skin, leading to false arrests. AI systems trained primarily on lighter-skinned faces perpetuate this bias.

hiringDiscrimination.title: Hiring Algorithm Discrimination
hiringDiscrimination.description: Amazon scrapped an AI recruiting tool that discriminated against women. Trained on resumes from male-dominated tech industry, it penalized resumes containing the word 'women's'.

creditScoring.title: Credit Scoring Fairness
creditScoring.description: AI credit systems must avoid discrimination based on protected characteristics like race, gender, or zip code, while still accurately assessing risk.

healthcareTransparency.title: Healthcare AI Transparency
healthcareTransparency.description: Doctors need to understand why an AI recommends a treatment. Black-box systems without explanations are unsuitable for medical decisions.

numpy.title: Python for AI: NumPy Fundamentals
numpy.description: The foundation of data science and AI in Python
numpy.overview: NumPy (Numerical Python) is the foundation of data science and AI in Python. It provides powerful tools for working with arrays and matrices, which are essential for machine learning algorithms.
numpy.whyNumPy: Machine learning works with large datasets represented as multi-dimensional arrays. NumPy makes operations on these arrays incredibly fast (often 50-100x faster than pure Python) through vectorization and optimized C code.
keyPoints: NumPy arrays are faster and more memory-efficient than Python lists
Vectorization allows operations on entire arrays without loops
Arrays can be 1D (vectors), 2D (matrices), or higher dimensions
NumPy is the foundation of pandas, TensorFlow, and scikit-learn
Essential for data preprocessing, feature engineering, and model implementation

pandas.title: Python for AI: Pandas for Data Manipulation
pandas.description: The go-to library for data manipulation and analysis
pandas.overview: Pandas is the go-to library for data manipulation and analysis in Python. While NumPy works with arrays, Pandas works with DataFrames - spreadsheet-like structures with labeled rows and columns.
pandas.whyPandas: Real-world data is messy - missing values, different data types, dates, categories. Pandas makes it easy to clean, transform, and prepare data for machine learning. It's the bridge between raw data and ML-ready datasets.
keyPoints: DataFrames are labeled 2D tables, Series are labeled 1D arrays
Handle missing data, merge datasets, group by categories
Read/write CSV, Excel, JSON, SQL databases easily
Filter and select data with powerful indexing
Essential for data cleaning and feature engineering

agenticAI.title: What is Agentic AI? The Future of Autonomous Systems
agenticAI.description: AI systems that can act autonomously to achieve goals
agenticAI.overview: Agentic AI represents the next evolution in artificial intelligence - systems that can act autonomously to achieve goals, make decisions, use tools, and adapt to changing environments without constant human intervention.
agenticAI.traditionalVsAgentic: Traditional AI responds to inputs (you ask ChatGPT a question, it answers). Agentic AI takes initiative - it can break down complex goals into steps, use multiple tools, remember context, learn from feedback, and execute multi-step plans autonomously.

keyCharacteristics.autonomy: Autonomy: Can operate independently without human guidance for each step
keyCharacteristics.goalOriented: Goal-Oriented: Works toward defined objectives, not just responding to prompts
keyCharacteristics.toolUse: Tool Use: Can access and use external tools (search, calculators, APIs, databases)
keyCharacteristics.planning: Planning: Breaks complex tasks into sub-tasks and executes them in sequence
keyCharacteristics.memory: Memory: Maintains context across interactions and learns from experience
keyCharacteristics.adaptability: Adaptability: Adjusts strategy based on results and feedback

researchAgent.title: Research Agent
researchAgent.description: You ask 'What are the top AI trends in 2025?' Agent searches web, reads articles, compares sources, synthesizes findings, creates report.
researchAgent.example: Goal: Research report → Agent: Search → Read → Analyze → Summarize → Present

codingAgent.title: Coding Agent (Devin)
codingAgent.description: You describe a feature. Agent writes code, runs tests, debugs errors, refactors, commits to GitHub - all autonomously.
codingAgent.example: Goal: 'Add login feature' → Agent: Plan → Code → Test → Debug → Deploy

personalAssistant.title: Personal Assistant Agent
personalAssistant.description: You say 'Book a trip to Paris'. Agent checks flights, hotels, creates itinerary, books reservations, adds to calendar.
personalAssistant.example: Goal: Paris trip → Agent: Search → Compare → Book → Organize → Confirm

customerService.title: Customer Service Agent
customerService.description: Customer: 'My order is late'. Agent checks order status, finds issue, updates shipping, sends tracking, offers discount.
customerService.example: Goal: Resolve complaint → Agent: Diagnose → Act → Update → Follow-up
